articles.headline: Outside Groups With Deep Pockets Lift G.O.P.
articles.snippet: The election was a pivotal moment for the “super PACs” and political nonprofit groups that helped the party defeat Democrats across the country.
articles.abstract: The election was a pivotal moment for the “super PACs” and political nonprofit groups that helped the party defeat Democrats across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last fall, Steven Law, the president of the nation’s largest Republican “super PAC,” met with two of his party’s biggest donors in a Houston office. Both had given generously to Mr. Law’s organization, American Crossroads, and other Republican outside groups in 2012, when they spent more than $700 million but failed to defeat President Obama or flip the Senate to Republican control. The donors were polite but incredulous.

articles.headline: Business Leaders Cautiously Expect G.O.P. Win to Open Some Doors
articles.snippet: Issues expected to get a new look include a corporate tax overhaul, environmental and financial regulation, trade deals and the Keystone oil pipeline.
articles.abstract: Issues expected to get a new look include a corporate tax overhaul, environmental and financial regulation, trade deals and the Keystone oil pipeline.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of gridlock in Washington, American business is gearing up for a major push on long-sought goals like an overhaul of the corporate tax system, building the Keystone XL oil pipeline, lighter environmental and financial regulation and winning congressional backing for trade deals with Asia and Europe. Business interests face a much more receptive audience now that Republicans are poised to control both the House and Senate next year.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: Fall of the Banner Ad: The Monster That Swallowed the Web
articles.snippet: In the 20 years since their introduction, banner ads have ruined the appearance and usability of the web, perverted content and diminished privacy.
articles.abstract: In the 20 years since their introduction, banner ads have ruined the appearance and usability of the web, perverted content and diminished privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago last month, a team of well-meaning designers, coders and magazine publishers inadvertently unleashed on an unsuspecting world one of the most misguided and destructive technologies of the Internet age: the web banner ad.

articles.headline: One Star, 2 Films and Conflict
articles.snippet: A publicity scuffle over Jessica Chastain, who appears in both “Interstellar” and “A Most Violent Year,” exemplifies how actors and filmmakers occasionally face conflicts over overlapping films.
articles.abstract: A publicity scuffle over Jessica Chastain, who appears in both “Interstellar” and “A Most Violent Year,” exemplifies how actors and filmmakers occasionally face conflicts over overlapping films.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Take a good look when Jessica Chastain walks the red carpet at a Hollywood premiere for J. C. Chandor’s “A Most Violent Year” on Thursday night.

articles.headline: A Pritzker Sets Out With Ideas of Empire
articles.snippet: Adam Pritzker, a member of the family behind Hyatt hotels, has started Assembled Brands, with ambitions of building his own consumer goods and hospitality conglomerate.
articles.abstract: Adam Pritzker, a member of the family behind Hyatt hotels, has started Assembled Brands, with ambitions of building his own consumer goods and hospitality conglomerate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Adam Pritzker strolled through a spacious SoHo loft, pausing to admire a fake narwhal tusk. Handblown glass chandeliers from the Czech Republic dangled overhead, and vintage Moroccan rugs covered expansive hardwood floors.

articles.headline: In Japan, Moves to Stimulate Economy Reach a Critical Stage
articles.snippet: Two years into an aggressive stimulus under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, his campaign to reinvigorate Japan’s economy is entering a make-or-break phase.
articles.abstract: Two years into an aggressive stimulus under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, his campaign to reinvigorate Japan’s economy is entering a make-or-break phase.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Hiroyuki Hara has increased prices at his flower shop in recent months, part of a broad reversal of the deflation that has long plagued Japan’s economy. Getting prices rising is a national goal, but Mr. Hara isn’t sure the new landscape is any more vibrant.

articles.headline: Known as ‘Alex From Target,’ Teenage Clerk Rises to Star on Twitter and Talk Shows
articles.snippet: While many people focused on the midterm elections, others became enamored of a young employee at a Target store in Texas.
articles.abstract: While many people focused on the midterm elections, others became enamored of a young employee at a Target store in Texas.
articles.lead_paragraph: While political analysts spent Wednesday interpreting the significance of the midterm elections, social media pundits obsessed over the meaning of Alex from Target.

articles.headline: Swamped in a Red Surge, Southern Democrats Contemplate Their Rebuilding Plans
articles.snippet: After decades of decline from once-total control of the South, Democrats already had little left to lose before the election.
articles.abstract: After decades of decline from once-total control of the South, Democrats already had little left to lose before the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Burns Strider, a native Mississippian who has advised the Democratic Party on faith issues, spent Tuesday night watching the election returns with a couple of other Democratic consultants and a bottle of small-batch bourbon. It was that kind of night.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and Richard Fausset

articles.headline: In States Seen to Be Tilting Left, Voters Defy Democrats’ Forecast
articles.snippet: A powerful lesson for both parties emerged Tuesday: Demographic shifts that are gradually reshaping the American electorate cannot overcome a difficult political environment and a weak message.
articles.abstract: A powerful lesson for both parties emerged Tuesday: Demographic shifts that are gradually reshaping the American electorate cannot overcome a difficult political environment and a weak message.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republicans working on the Senate race in Colorado sensed something was shifting even before the votes were counted.

articles.headline: Effort Begins for More Say on Directors
articles.snippet: Scott Stringer, the New York City comptroller who oversees five pension funds, is leading a drive to let shareholders nominate board directors.
articles.abstract: Scott Stringer, the New York City comptroller who oversees five pension funds, is leading a drive to let shareholders nominate board directors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Annual shareholder meetings are supposed to allow a company’s owners to change troubling governance practices such as outsize executive pay or directors who neglect their fiduciary duties.

articles.headline: For Draghi, Promises Are Still His Main Policy Option
articles.snippet: Forced to coax consensus, the European Central Bank chief must rely on statements of resolve, unspooling monetary policy in monthly increments.
articles.abstract: Forced to coax consensus, the European Central Bank chief must rely on statements of resolve, unspooling monetary policy in monthly increments.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Mario Draghi may have invented a new kind of policy tool. Call it verbal quantitative easing.

articles.headline: Microsoft, Changing Tack, Makes Office Suite Free on Mobile
articles.snippet: In a sign of the seismic changes underway in the tech industry, Microsoft will give away the software for iPads, iPhones and Android tablets.
articles.abstract: In a sign of the seismic changes underway in the tech industry, Microsoft will give away the software for iPads, iPhones and Android tablets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Few golden geese in technology have survived as long as Office has for Microsoft.

articles.headline: Myanmar Policy’s Message to Muslims: Get Out
articles.snippet: A government plan to resettle Muslim minorities who cannot meet strict standards for naturalized citizenship has spurred a major exodus, rights groups say.
articles.abstract: A government plan to resettle Muslim minorities who cannot meet strict standards for naturalized citizenship has spurred a major exodus, rights groups say.
articles.lead_paragraph: SITTWE, Myanmar — The Myanmar government has given the estimated one million Rohingya people in this coastal region of the country a dispiriting choice: Prove your family has lived here for more than 60 years and qualify for second-class citizenship, or be placed in camps and face deportation.
